Name: Technical Controls
Description:
• Controls implemented using systems
• Operating system controls
• Firewalls, anti-virus

Name: Managerial Controls
Description:
• Administrative controls associated with security design and implementation
• Security policies, standard operating procedures

Name: Operational Controls
Description:
• Controls implemented by people instead of systems
• Security guards, awareness program

Name: Physical Controls
Description:
• Limit physical access
• Guard shack
• Fences, locks
• Badge readers

Name: Control Types
Description:
• Preventive
• Deterrent
• Detective
• Corrective
• Compensating
• Directive

Name: Preventive
Description: • Block access

Name: Deterrent
Description: • Discourage intrusion attempt

Name: Corrective
Description: • Apply control using other means

Name: Directive
Description: • Direct a subject towards security compliance

Name: CIA Triad
Description:
• Confidentiality
• Integrity
• Availability

Name: Confidentiality
Description:
• Certain information should only be known to certain people
• Encryption
• Access controls
• Two-factor authentication

Name: Integrity
Description: • Data is stored and transferred as intended

Name: Examples of Integrity
Description:
1. Hashing – map data of arbitrary length to fixed length
2. Digital signatures – verify data integrity
3. Certificates – used with digital signatures to verify an individual
4. Non-repudiation – provides proof of integrity

Name: Availability
Description: • Information is accessible to authorized users

Name: Examples of Availability
Description:
1. Redundancy – build services that will always be available
2. Fault tolerance – system continues to run even when a failure occurs
3. Patching – maintain stability and close security holes

Name: Non-Repudiation
Description:
• You can't deny what you've said
• Proof of integrity
• Proof of origin

Name: Proof of Integrity
Description: • Verify data does not change

Name: Hash
Description:
• Used in cryptography
• Represent data as a short string of text
• If data changes, the hash changes
• Does not necessarily associate data with an individual

Name: Proof of Origin
Description:
• Proves the message was not changed – Integrity
• Proves the source of the message – Authentication
• Ensures the signature isn't fake – Non-repudiation

Name: Examples of Proof of Origin
Description:
• Private Key – Sign
• Public Key – Verify

Name: AAA Framework
Description:
• Identification
• Authentication
• Authorization
• Accounting

Name: Identification
Description: • Username

Name: Authentication
Description: • Password and other authentication factors

Name: Authorization
Description: • Determine access to resources based on role

Name: Accounting
Description: • Record login time, data sent and received, and logout time

Name: Authenticating People
Description:
1. Enter username and password
2. Goes to VPN/Firewall
3. Checks identification via AAA Server
4. If approved, goes back to VPN/Firewall
5. Then goes to Internal File Server

Name: Authenticating Systems
Description: • Use signed certificate on the device

Name: Certificate Authentication
Description:
• Certificate Authority (CA)
• Most organizations maintain their own CAs

Name: CA Process
Description:
1. Organization creates a certificate for a device
2. Digitally signs the certificate with the organization's CA
3. Certificate can now be included on a device as an authentication factor
4. CA's digital signature is used to validate the certificate

Name: Authorization Models
Description:
• Users and services → data and applications
• Defined by roles, organizations, attributes, etc.

Name: Abstraction
Description:
• Reduce complexity
• Create a clear relationship between the user and the resource
• Administration is streamlined
• Easy to understand authorizations
• Support any number of users or resources

Name: Gap Analysis
Description:
• Where you are → Where you want to be
• Can take a long time
• Can require many people

Name: Baseline
Description:
• Internal set of goals
• Some organizations use formal standards
• Used to evaluate people and processes

Name: Compare and Contrast
Description:
• Compare – evaluate existing systems
• Identify weaknesses
• Perform detailed analysis

Name: Analysis and Report
Description:
• Final comparison – detailed baseline
• Path to goals
• Create gap analysis report

Name: Zero Trust
Description:
• Holistic approach to network security
• Covers every device, process, and person
• Everything must be verified
• Nothing is inherently trusted

Name: Planes of Operation
Description:
• Split the network into functional planes
• Applies to physical, virtual, and cloud components

Name: Data Plane
Description:
• Processes frames, packets, and network data
• Handles forwarding, trunking, encrypting, and NAT

Name: Control Plane
Description:
• Manages the actions of the data plane
• Defines policies and rules
• Determines how packets should be forwarded
• Routing tables, session tables, NAT tables

Name: Adaptive Identity
Description:
• Controls trust dynamically
• Examines identity based on provided credentials and other authentication data

Name: Threat Scope Reduction
Description:
• Reduces the number of possible entry points
• Minimizes exposure by controlling trust

Name: Policy Driven Access Control
Description: • Combines adaptive identity with predefined rules to manage access

Name: Security Zones
Description:
• Define source and destination trust levels
• Trusted → Untrusted
• Internal network → External network

Name: Policy Enforcement Point
Description:
• Subjects and systems: users, apps, non-human entities
• Acts as a gatekeeper
• Allows, monitors, and terminates connections

Name: Policy Decision Point
Description:
• Evaluates each access request based on policy and data sources
• Grants, denies, or revokes access

Name: Policy Administrator
Description:
• Communicates with the Policy Enforcement Point
• Generates access tokens or credentials
• Instructs PEP to allow or disallow access

Name: Policy Engine
Description:
• Evaluates access decisions based on policy and other inputs
• Grants, denies, or revokes access

Name: Barricades and Bollards
Description:
• Prevent access
• Channel people through a specific entry point
• Identify safety concerns

Name: Access Control Vestibules
Description: • Allow or control access to secure areas

Name: Fence
Description: • Create a physical perimeter for security

Name: CCTV
Description: • Closed-circuit television for video surveillance

Name: Guards and Access Badges
Description:
• Provide physical protection and identification
• Support two-person integrity/control
• Access badge – employee ID badge

Name: Honeypots
Description:
• Attract attackers into isolated environments
• Simulate real systems to collect threat data

Name: Honeynets
Description: • Larger deception networks built from multiple honeypots

Name: Honeyfiles
Description:
• Fake files used as bait within a honeynet
• Generate alerts when accessed

Name: Honeytokens
Description:
• Traceable data planted to track malicious activity
• Reveal where stolen information is used

Name: Change Management
Description:
• Formal process for managing change
• Prevent downtime, confusion, and mistakes

Name: Change Management Process
Description:
1. Complete request forms
2. Determine the purpose of the change
3. Identify scope and impact
4. Schedule date/time
5. Analyze risk and obtain approval
6. Implement and test
7. Document and get end-user acceptance

Name: Ownership
Description: • Individual or entity responsible for initiating and managing the change

Name: Stakeholders
Description: • Individuals or groups impacted by the change

Name: Impact Analysis
Description:
• Determine the risk level of the change
• Consider risks of not making the change

Name: Sandbox
Description: • Isolated testing environment with no connection to production systems

Name: Backout Plan
Description:
• Plan to revert to previous state if issues occur
• Always maintain backups

Name: Maintenance Window
Description: • Scheduled time period for performing changes

Name: SOP (Standard Operating Procedure)
Description: • Change management must be documented and repeatable

Name: Allow List
Description:
• Only approved software or processes can run
• Highly restrictive

Name: Deny List
Description:
• Blocks known malicious or disallowed software
• Implemented via anti-virus or anti-malware tools

Name: Downtime
Description:
• Schedule maintenance during non-production hours
• Minimize downtime using redundancy

Name: Legacy Applications
Description:
• Unsupported software that requires custom maintenance
• Create specific procedures for stability

Name: Documentation
Description: • Update diagrams, policies, and procedures during change processes

Name: Version Control
Description:
• Track configuration changes over time
• Enable rollback to previous settings
• Examples: router configs, OS updates
